title: Areopagitica

cover.alt: Title page beginning 'AREOPAGITICA / A / SPEECH . OR / Mr. JOHN MILTON / For the Liberty of Vnlicenc'd / PRINTING, / To the Parlament of ENGLAND'.  Following this are two quotations from Euripides (one in Greek, one English), and 'LONDON / Printed in the Yeare, 1644'.

overview: Published in response to England's 1643 Licensing Order, which required publishers to get permission from the government to print new works, this tract has become a classic and often-referenced defense of freedom of the press.

incidents.comment: Below is from 12 Banned Books, pp. 20-21
incidents.description: As this book was deliberately printed in defiance of the Licensing Order, it was effectively automatically banned legally from the time of publication. (Other rules that require permission from external authorities before a publisher can print a book, a librarian or bookseller can stock it, or a teacher can teach from it, can effectively work as bans in much the same way.)   <cite>Areopagita</cite> was also explicitly condemned by Lord Protector Oliver Cromwell in 1658.  England's licensing regime continued until 1694, 20 years after Milton's death.  After 1644, this book was not republished until 1738.
